column1: A magnet is a material or object that produces a magnetic field. This magnetic field is invisible but is responsible for the most notable property of a magnet: a force that pulls on other ferromagnetic materials
column3: and attracts or repels other magnets. A permanent magnet is an object made from a material that is magnetized and creates its own persistent magnetic field. An everyday example is a refrigerator magnet used to hold notes on a refrigerator door. Materials that can be magnetized
column4: which are also the ones that are strongly attracted to a magnet
column5: are called ferromagnetic (or ferrimagnetic). These include iron
column8: some alloys of rare earth metals
column9: and some naturally occurring minerals such as lodestone. Although ferromagnetic (and ferrimagnetic) materials are the only ones attracted to a magnet strongly enough to be commonly considered magnetic
column10: all other substances respond weakly to a magnetic field
column11: by one of several other types of magnetism.
